UMP 2020 Naik 8,51 Persen, Pengusaha Cemas Investor Kabur
06 Nov 2019, 03:46 by Eko Wahyudi, Rahma Tri
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Ketua Umum Kamar Dagang dan Industri (Kadin) Indonesia Rosan Perkasa Roeslani khawatir jika aturan kenaikan upah minimum provinsi (UMP) 2020 sebesar 8,51 persen, akan membuat investor berpikir ulang untuk masuk ke Indonesia. Sebab, investor akan menghitung ulang biaya produksi yang membengkank.
Lebih dari itu, Rosan juga khawatir jika industri yang sudah ada di dalam negeri pun justru ikut hengkang karena gaji yang harus dibayarkan terlalu tinggi. "Kalau pindahnya secara bertahap mending, pindahnya masih di Indonesia. Nah kalau pindahnya ke negara lain itu kan jadi non produktif. Kalau naiknya tinggi, enggak ada investasi yang masuk, yang ada malah relokasi. Jadi memang harus cari keselarasan," kata dia di Hotel Indonesia Kempinski, Jakarta, Selasa, 5 November 2019.
Sebagai pengusaha, Rosan pun mengakui harus menerima aturan UMP yang telah ditetapkan pemerintah. Apalagi, aturan itu telah diketok palu dengan formula kenaikan yang mengandalkan pertumbuhan ekonomi ditambah angka inflasi dalam negeri. Namun Rosan tetap menilai kenaikan UMP ini akan menjadi beban tersendiri bagi industri padat karya.
Oleh karena itu dirinya mengusulkan untuk kenaikan UMP setiap daerah harus dibedakan, karena ada beberapa wilayah upah minimun itu sudah terlalu tinggi. Artinya, jika perusahaan di kawasan itu menerapkan aturan tersebut, maka UMP-nya akan semakin melambung. "Lalu industri akan berpindah ke mana?," kata dia.
Rosan menyarankan pemerintah mengkaji dulu kelayakan kenaikan UMP di setiap daerah. Misalnya, melihat dari faktor lain dari segi penyerapan tenaga kerja di wilayah tersebut. Lalu dilihat apakah di situ banyak usaha mikro kecil dan menengah (UMKM).
Menurutnya, ada daerah yang memiliki UMP sekitar Rp 1,7 juta saja namun ada pula yang sampai Rp 4 juta lebih. Akibatnya, dikhawatirkan akan ada eksodus investor ke provinsi lain, bahkan mungkin hingga negara lain. "Jadi jangan disamaratakan dulu," kata dia.
Rosan menilai, jika setiap daerah menggunakan formula yang sama, maka gap atau selisih UMP antar daerah akan semakin jauh. Sedangkan, produktivitas pekerja sama. "Itu juga yang kita beri masukan ke pemerintah, mungkin kenaikan itu jangan sama dulu semua."
text:
UMP 2020 Increases 8.51 Percent, Entrepreneurs Are Anxious For Blur Investors
Nov 6, 2019, 03:46 by Eko Wahyudi, Rahma Tri
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Chairperson of the Indonesian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (Kadin) Rosan Perkasa Roeslani is concerned that the 2020 minimum wage (UMP) increase of 8.51 percent will make investors rethink investors to enter Indonesia. Because, investors will recalculate the production costs which will increase.
More than that, Rosan is also worried that the industry that already exists in the country will also leave because the salaries to be paid are too high. "If the move is gradually better, the move is still in Indonesia. Now if you move to another country, it will become non-productive. If the increase is high, no investment will come in, instead there will be relocation. So we have to look for harmony," he said at the Hotel Indonesia Kempinski, Jakarta, Tuesday, 5 November 2019.
As a businessman, Rosan also admitted that he had to accept the UMP rules set by the government. Moreover, the regulation has been hammered with an increase formula that relies on economic growth plus domestic inflation. But Rosan still thinks that the increase in the UMP will be a burden for labor-intensive industries.
Therefore, he proposed that the increase in the UMP for each region must be distinguished, because there are some areas that the minimum wage is already too high. That is, if companies in the region implement these rules, the UMP will be more inflated. "Then where will the industry move ?," he said.
Rosan suggested that the government first assess the feasibility of increasing the UMP in each region. For example, looking at other factors in terms of employment in the region. Then see whether there are many micro small and medium enterprises (MSMEs).
According to him, there are regions that have a UMP of around Rp. 1.7 million, but there are also up to Rp. 4 million more. As a result, it is feared that there will be an exodus of investors to other provinces, maybe even to other countries. "So don't generalize yet," he said.
Rosan assessed, if each region uses the same formula, the gap or difference in the UMP between regions will be further away. Meanwhile, worker productivity is the same. "That is also what we gave input to the government, maybe the increase is not the same for all."
